Award.AwardTitle: Memory of a Drought: Training Arabidopsis Plants to Withstand Dehydration Stress

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Sensing environmental changes and initiating an adequate response is critical for a plant's survival. Previous exposure to a stress can make a plant more resistant to future exposures by producing faster and/or stronger reactions to the stress. Altered responses imply that plants exercise a form of "memory" from a previous stress suggesting that plants could be "trained" to withstand future stresses. However, the mechanisms involved in plant stress memory are unknown leaving a fundamental biological question unanswered. The goals of this project are to examine whether repetitive dehydration stress causes altered responses indicative of plant's "stress memory" and to reveal factors involved in the mechanism. The specific aims are: 1) To analyze the plant's transcriptional and physiological responses to multiple dehydration stress treatments with the purpose of identifying the subset of trainable genes; 2) To identify genes demonstrating epigenetic memory by identifying trainable genes with persistently high levels of epigenetic marks; 3) To examine the roles of the ATX1 chromatin modifying protein and the hormone Abscisic Acid (ABA) in dehydration stress memory and training. Results from this study may broadly impact research on other types of plant stresses. A long term practical goal is to enhance the ability to generate crops that can better withstand recurring patterns of drought spells. This should be a fruitful area for future research both in terms of new science and in terms of applied value.

Broader Impacts: The proposed activities will positively impact human resource development through the direct training of scientists at the undergraduate, graduate and postgraduate level. Schools in rural Nebraska supply classes and laboratories with enthusiastic and motivated undergraduate students. The project will emphasize recruitment of students from underrepresented groups and encourage them to consider a career in biology. To further integrate research with education, undergraduate students will be engaged in small individual bioinformatics research projects, and week-long summer workshops will be organized for students from small liberal arts colleges. Also, the project will continue to be involved with University outreach programs for science teachers from the Lincoln high schools with the goal of acquainting them with cutting-edge genome/epigenome analyses and technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The transcriptional memory responses to repeated dehydration stress and the evolutionary conservation of these plant attributes open a new area for research of mechanisms regulating gene transcription and epigenetic effects. Understanding the physiological and the molecular basis of plant memory responses to repeated dehydration stress may have practical implication in the efforts to make plants better prepared to resist recurring bouts of drought and improve survival under changing climate conditions. In addition, our results have provided some basic insights at the molecular level into the mechanisms regulating plants responses mediated by biotic and abiotic stress signaling pathways. The results may have significance for studies of the interaction between the stress-signaling responses mediated by different plant hormones. 

The results have been published in 12 papers in peer-reviewed journals. The results reported in Nature Communications, 2012, were met with high interest and were covered and commented in international media outlets. Some of the results obtained during the course of this research were reported at an invited talk at a Keystone meeting in 2016 (Taos, NM). All papers, except the most recent, have been referenced by other research groups.

In addition to basic science research, we are involved in training of young scientists at all levels, emphasizing recruitment of students from underrepresented groups, in particular. Some of our undergraduate students come from rural Nebraskan families as first-generation college students. The goal was to expose them to scientific ideas and concepts and to encouraging them to consider future careers in science.  A number of them did continue with graduate studies at medical schools, or as PhD students at different universities, i.e., Harvard, Rutgers, Georgetown, UNMC, etc. Some have already graduated and are practicing doctors, teachers in the Lincoln public school system, and workers in biotech companies.  All of them have been partially supported by NSF-REU funds.     

In an effort to further integrate research with education, we have provided opportunities for the students to participate in both laboratory research and computational analysis and mining of the data, through the mentoring program of Dr. Riethoven and the Bioinformatic facility at UNL. We have delivered a number of lectures and participated in workshops demonstrating cutting-edge technologies for genome analyses and research in gene expression and epigenetics to students from Lincoln high schools through a program supported by EPSCoR.  

We are actively mentoring and training graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. Their contribution is reflected in their participation as co-authors of all papers published from our labs. In addition, we try to prepare them for future independent careers by encouraging them to attend grant-writing workshops and involving them in mentoring activities of junior students in the lab.  

The success of our mentoring is evidenced by the fact that all of our PostDocs have moved on to faculty or to research scientist positions at Universities in the USA (Duke, USD; Emory, Brody School of Medicine, ENC) and abroad (i.e., Mexico, Jordan, China).
